etymologies: late Middle English (originally as an alchemical term denoting the process of reducing a volatile spirit or essence to a permanent bodily form): from medieval Latin fixatio(n-), from fixare (see fix)

definitions: an obsessive interest in or feeling about someone or something

examples.text: our fixation with diet and fitness
his fixation on the details of other people's erotic lives

definitions: the arresting of part of the libido at an immature stage, causing an obsessive attachment

examples.text: fixation at the oral phase might result in dependence on others

definitions: the action of making something firm or stable
the process by which some plants and microorganisms incorporate gaseous nitrogen or carbon dioxide to form nongaseous compounds

examples.text: his work on nitrogen fixation in plants

shortDefinitions: process by which plants fix nitrogen

definitions: the process of preserving or stabilizing (a specimen) with a chemical substance prior to microscopy or other examination

examples.text: biopsy specimens were placed in cassettes before fixation in formalin

definitions: the action of concentrating the eyes directly on something

examples.text: during the period of total blindness there was a complete absence of visual fixation

shortDefinitions: action of concentrating eyes on something
